 Well, I had to look up what NT-NCF was supposed to be. Here it is, from the post that began this forum:
 
 
Evolutionary theory itself preaches and teaches No-Teleology-No-Conscious-Forethought.

 
 Well, two things. First, evolution is a fact. We can see evolution operating over small scales today, and there is plenty of geological and genetic evidence that suggests the close ancestral kinship of all life on earth. No biologists deny evolution, somehow, happened. However, the fact THAT evolution happened doesn't necessitate any particular theory about HOW it happened. It's mere fact doesn't in principle exclude teleology, design, or even intelligent involvement in explaining how it happened.
 
 Second, does the currently dominant scientific theory of evolution, the new Darwinian synthesis, assume or require the absence of teleology and intelligent design? Certainly, prominent biologists have argued this, but in a special way: like all of natural science, the theory of evolution doesn't NEED assumptions of teleology or intelligent intent by a designer, because it invokes the demonstrated self-organising properties of matter, coupled to the non-random process of natural selection, which sieves out good variants from bad ones in the context of any given environment.
 
 That process must logically result in adaptation over many generations of any lineage that reproduces by repetitively following the basic rules of evolutionary theory: vary, inherit, select. No intelligent planning or foresight is needed. It is mimicked in modern genetic algorithms in computers built to generate complex engineering designs. In GA's, blind, evolutionary processes can zero in on optimal designs much faster than intelligent human engineers, and have been used successfully in airplane design. In all these cases, the final design is not known by the human engineer, who only programs the rules of the genetic algorithm and the standards for success (the selection sieve), and not the details of the final design... it is arrived at blindly, because evolutionary algorithms are astonishingly efficient at finding rare good design in a jungle of possibilities. This is a matter of fact now, and not mere theory.
 
 While science cannot formally exclude teleology or an intelligent designer in evolution, it certainly doesn't need to appeal to them to provide a valid scientific explanation for the fact of evolution. Natural selection appears to suffice to explain the evolution of complexity by the application of simple selective rules to random variants in a population: this has been demonstrated theoretically for such a system as the camera eye, starting from flat components. In short, there is no fundamental theoretical or logical obstacle to deriving complex systems from initially simple ones, merely by repetitively applying an algorithm of vary, inherit and select. We don't see the evolution of complex organs such as an eye in real time, because they take hundreds of thousands of generations to accomplish, and no scientist or society is going to live long enough to carry out such an experiment. However, we can observe the real time evolution of smaller complex systems, such as enzymes, which is proof of concept.
 
 Worse, if scientists did appeal to teleology and designers, they'd cease to do science, because science is about finding naturalistic explanations for natural phenomena. There is no way it can ask a supernatural designer how or why certain designs were supposedly selected over others, and biology would once again be reduced to mere stamp collecting, without any systematic explanations of why the biological world appears as it does. With ID Creationism, every explanation is effectively reduced to saying: It exists the way it does, because that's the way God intended it to be.
 
 That is the antithesis of science; that's pure religion. And even if scientists were to come to the conclusion that terrestrial life had been the result of deliberate design by some entity, say let's suppose that entity dropped down to earth and explained how and why they did it, that doesn't answer the question of how the entity came to be. It merely shoves the same problem one level up.
 
 So if it's science you want, the new Darwinian synthesis, for all the modifications it's likely to see over the next few years, is still the principal player in the scientific game. And even if it were replaced, it won't be by ID Creationism or that so-called oxymoron, Creation Science. They can't wish the facts of evolution away, nor can they appeal to the supernatural while claiming to be doing science.
 
 To return to the original question, it has not been shown that Darwinian theory supports or necessitates eugenics. Eugenics is not supported by current biological evidence, because it isn't really a science, it's a currently discredited social philosophy that people in lower social classes are less fit to breed, according to the standards of people in higher classes.
